summaries.body: The A.C.L.U. asked a federal appeals court to partly shut down the N.S.A. program that collects Americans’ phone records in bulk, which resumed last month after a lapse.
The Supreme Court declined to stop the execution of a man convicted of sexually assaulting and murdering a teenager. The execution was set for 8 p.m. Eastern.

display_asset.caption: Rob Manfred, the M.L.B. commissioner, at a game last month in San Francisco. On Tuesday, he said M.L.B. had a list of cities it thought were "viable" sites for expansion teams.

summaries.body: Rob Manfred, the Major League Baseball commissioner, said he is open to adding new teams. With 30 franchises, the league has not expanded since 1998.
Planned Parenthood said a secretly recorded video uploaded online falsely portrayed its participation in the sale of tissue and body parts from aborted fetuses.
Aaron Kromer, the offensive line coach for the Buffalo Bills, was placed on indefinite paid leave after he was accused of punching and threatening a boy.

display_asset.caption: Leland and Sharon Bowman were on a plane that took off on Saturday afternoon from Kalispell, Mont., but never arrived at its destination in Lynden, Wash.

summaries.body: After a plane crashed in Washington State, a 16-year-old passenger tried to pull her stepgrandparents out of the wreckage before leaving to get help, an official said.
A federal judge ordered the release of a video showing the police in a Los Angeles suburb fatally shooting an unarmed man in 2013.
Dale Cox, the acting district attorney in Caddo Parrish, La., said he will not run for election in the fall after comments he made on the death penalty stirred controversy.
President Obama spoke at the N.A.A.C.P.'s annual national convention in Philadelphia.
The U.S. expressed concern about Bahrain's treatment of opposition figures after a Sunni leader was arrested and accused of plotting to overthrow the monarchy.
Wal-Mart Stores was accused of discrimination in a lawsuit filed in Boston federal court by an employee who said the company failed to extend health insurance to her wife.
A report attributed to Bloomberg News saying that Twitter Inc. received an offer to be acquired for $31 billion was fake, a spokesman said. Twitter shares rose on the report.
Attorneys are giving their closing arguments on Tuesday in the trial of James E. Holmes, who is charged with killing 12 people in a Colorado theater in 2012.

display_asset.caption: France celebrated Bastille Day on Tuesday with President François Hollande, and Mexican President Enrique Peña Nieto, watching a parade of military hardware.
display_asset.title: Scenes of France’s Bastille Day Parade

summaries.body: Fresh from striking a blow for Europe, by mediating the tussle between Greece and Germany over debt, France feted France in its national Bastille Day parade.
Wells Fargo said second-quarter profit fell to $5.72 billion from $5.73 billion a year earlier. On an earnings per share basis, the bank’s profits rose to $1.03 up from $1.01.
Black children were almost four times as likely as white children to be living in poverty in 2013, possibly because of a higher unemployment rate for African-Americans.
Apple introduced mobile payments in Britain, making it available in 250,000 sites in a plan that will eventually be supported by all major British banks.
The U.N. said at least 142 civilians had been killed in Yemen over the past 10 days, bringing the total killed in airstrikes and ground fighting since March 26 to 1,670.

display_asset.caption: Jamie Dimon is chief of JPMorgan Chase, whose overall performance rose in the first quarter.

summaries.body: JPMorgan Chase reported second-quarter earnings of $1.54 a share, compared with $1.46 a year earlier. Follow the news here all week as the largest banks report their results.

display_asset.caption: Curtis Jackson, also known as 50 Cent, pictured on the roof of the G-Unit office near Times Square earlier this year, was ordered last week to pay $5 million over the release of a sex tape.
display_asset.credit: Alex Welsh for The New York Times

summaries.body: The rapper 50 Cent called his bankruptcy filing on Monday a "strategic business move" that would allow him to keep working on his music while reorganizing his finances.
At least 27 people died in a stampede at a religious festival in southern India, officials said.
Bicycle lanes have been introduced on some streets in Pyongyang, North Korea's capital, where car ownership is still rare but two-wheeled transportation less so.

posts.footer: A Times correspondent in Monroeville, Ala., Harper Lee's hometown, where the author's new novel "Go Set a Watchman" was released at midnight, via Twitter

summaries.body: Writing thank you notes to #harperlee at the #monroeville bookstore. http://t.co/cGtkeSdETW

posts.footer: From an anonymous note left at an Israeli museum with two sling stones, which the writer claimed to have taken from the ancient site of Gamla, via Haaretz

summaries.body: I stole them in July 1995 and since then they have brought me nothing but trouble.
Laura Poitras, who won an Oscar for her film about Edward J. Snowden, “Citizenfour,” sued several U.S. agencies, saying that airport security officials harassed her for years.
South Korea said two North Korean fishermen who drifted into its waters had been sent home. Three others who asked to defect remained, despite Pyongyang's protests.
Three knife-wielding "terrorists" from the western region of Xinjiang who attacked police officers in a northeastern Chinese city were shot and killed, state media reported.
An Australian editor and his Thai colleague went on trial in Thailand, charged with defaming the navy in an article on human trafficking. They could face seven years in prison.
An ex-lawyer was arrested in a kidnapping case that appears to be linked to Denise Huskins, whose disappearance in Vallejo, Calif., the police had suggested was a hoax.
G.M. became the first of the big three Detroit automakers to open talks on a new contract with the United Auto Workers union to replace a pact that expires in September.
An American is set to be the first woman to be in command of a mega-cruise ship. Kate McCue, of San Francisco, will sail to Bermuda from the East Coast.
The son of a Boston police captain, described as mentally ill and devoted to the Islamic State, plotted a series of deadly attacks, officials said.

display_asset.credit: Rahav Segev for The New York Times

summaries.body: An autopsy found no evidence that B.B. King was poisoned before he died of natural causes in May, as two of his children alleged.
A teenage girl emerged from the woods in Washington state on Monday two days after surviving a plane crash, a sheriff said. She was sent to the hospital with minor injuries.
A Pennsylvania court rejected an inmate's claim that he was not responsible for paying for medical treatment that the state forced on him while he was staging a hunger strike.
Two Moroccan women were acquitted of indecency charges for wearing short skirts in public, their lawyer said. Thousands had signed a petition supporting them.

display_asset.caption: Michelle Meyer, left, and Alexander Bukreyev conducted research on an inhaled Ebola vaccine. “This is one of the few vaccines that works,” Dr. Bukreyev said.
display_asset.credit: Christian Von Eschenbach/the University of Texas Medical Branch

summaries.body: A single dose of a new Ebola vaccine that can be inhaled has been found to neutralize the deadly virus in monkeys, a study said.
Dez Bryant, a star wide receiver for the Dallas Cowboys, suggested on Twitter that he would decline to play if a deal is not reached soon on a long-term contract.
The New York State paleontologist is answering reader questions about fossils and prehistoric life in the state. She is responding in the comments.
Lena Headey of "Game of Thrones" and HBO's John Oliver are joining the voice cast of the BBC's animated series "Danger Mouse."

display_asset.caption: A fan was hit in the head with a broken bat during an A's-Red Sox game at Fenway Park last month.

summaries.body: A proposed class-action lawsuit was filed against Major League Baseball accusing it of doing too little to protect fans from being injured by balls and splintered bats.
Netflix’s share price set a new record ahead of the company’s second-quarter earnings report, which is due July 15 after the market closes. Shares reached $716.16.
A former volunteer sheriff's deputy in Oklahoma who says he confused his handgun and stun gun when he killed an unarmed, restrained man will face a jury trial in February.

display_asset.credit: Christopher  Lee for The New York Times

summaries.body: A bicyclist was killed and three passengers in an S.U.V. were injured in a crash that involved three vehicles near the Barclays Center in Brooklyn, authorities said.
Curtis James Jackson III, the rapper known as 50 Cent, filed for bankruptcy protection. He has assets and debts each in the range of $10 million to $50 million, court papers said.
Berkeley Breathed, the Pulitzer Prize-winning creator and artist of “Bloom County,” has revived his vintage 1980s strip on his Facebook page after a hiatus of about 25 years.
China and North Korea will open a border trade zone in the northeastern Chinese city of Dandong, China's state news media said. It is expected to open in October.
Iraqi troops backed by mainly Shiite Muslim militias have started operations to recapture Anbar Province from Islamic State militants, a military statement said.
Malaysia is investigating whether government officials leaked records said to show hundreds of millions of dollars in transfers to Prime Minister Najib Razak and his wife.
Prosecutors in Romania temporarily seized the assets of Prime Minister Victor Ponta after indicting him in a corruption investigation.
Prince William started a new job as an air ambulance pilot on Monday. The prince, who is second in line to the British throne, will donate his salary to charity.

display_asset.caption: Demonstrators in Hong Kong on Sunday protesting the recent detentions of human rights lawyers in China. Albert Ho, center, of the Democratic Party wore mock handcuffs.

summaries.body: China has detained dozens of lawyers, accusing some of undermining the ruling party, dealing a blow to the “rights defense” movement that had sought to expand civic rights.

posts.footer: The governor of Wisconsin becomes the 15th prominent Republican to enter the 2016 race, via Twitter

summaries.body: I'm in. I'm running for president because Americans deserve a leader who will fight and win for them. - SW http://t.co/DZG253QjfP #Walker16
A group of gunmen broke into a discount clothing store near Paris, trapping 18 people inside for hours before fleeing and prompting a manhunt, the police said.
The United Arab Emirates executed an Abu Dhabi woman with links to Islamic extremists who was convicted of murdering an American teacher in a local mall last year.
Tenzin Delek Rinpoche, a prominent Tibetan religious leader, has died in a Chinese prison, according to a family member and a Tibetan exile group.
Cambodia's legislature passed a law, criticized by the United Nations, that empowers the government to shut down nongovernmental organizations on vague grounds.

posts.footer: The president of the European Council, via Twitter

summaries.body: EuroSummit has unanimously reached agreement. All ready to go for ESM programme for #Greece with serious reforms & financial support
Climate change demonstrators cut through a fence at Heathrow Airport and protested on a runway, disrupting flights. Above, police surround protestors on the ground.

posts.footer: The Times's Tehran bureau chief, via Twitter

summaries.body: Iran state TV is reporting "an announcement" on a 'Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action" to resolve the nuclear dispute will be made today.
Alaska is beginning a large-scale cleanup of debris from its shores, some of it thought to be from the tsunami that struck Japan in 2011.
China’s benchmark stock index rallied for a third day, as more companies resumed trading after last week's turmoil and trade data exceeded expectations.

display_asset.caption: The statue of William Shakespeare in Central Park on Saturday. Of the park’s 22 statues of historical figures, all are men.

summaries.body: Of the 22 statues of historical figures in Central Park (like one of Shakespeare, above), none are of women. A famed suffragist's great-great-granddaughter wants that changed.

posts.footer: Agence France-Presse, via The South China Morning Post

summaries.body: China has created a system that makes getting a passport "virtually impossible" for Tibetans and other ethnic minority groups, Human Rights Watch said.
Planes fighting a California wildfire were grounded to avoid collisions after a drone flew into the area, the fourth such incident in a month, the United States Forest Service said.
The Twitter account of Gov. Scott Walker of Wisconsin sent word that he was seeking the 2016 Republican nomination for president — perhaps inadvertently, perhaps not.
McDonald's denied accusations that its Happy Meal toys from the animated film "Minions" use foul language and said there were no plans to pull them from distribution.
Mike Moustakas of the Kansas City Royals and Carlos Martinez of the St. Louis Cardinals won the final fan votes and will go to the All-Star Game.
Yanis Varoufakis, the former Greek finance minister, wrote in an op-ed that creditors have refused to offer essential debt relief because of politics, not economics.
Dalvin Cook, a sophomore starting running back for Florida State, was charged with misdemeanor battery and suspended from the football team.
Characters on "The Simpsons" are often seen guzzling Duff Beer. Now 21st Century Fox, the media company, will sell a real-life version of the brew, starting in Chile.
The N.F.L. reduced its suspension for Greg Hardy, a Dallas Cowboys defensive end, from 10 games to four. He was suspended for his involvement in a domestic violence case.
LeBron James signed a one-year contract with the Cleveland Cavaliers on Friday. The deal has a player option for the 2016-17 season.
The presidents of Liberia, Guinea and Sierra Leone appealed for $3.2 billion to help the Ebola-hit countries recover from the epidemic.
The defense rested its case in the trial of James E. Holmes, who is charged with killing 12 people in a Colorado theater in 2012. Closing arguments are set to begin Tuesday.
Farid Fata, a Michigan doctor, was sentenced to 45 years in prison for a Medicare fraud scheme that involved giving chemotherapy to patients who did not have cancer.
General Motors said it was recalling nearly 780,000 crossover SUVs, mainly in North America, because their rear power lift gates could fall and hit people.
Japan’s new satellite captures an image every 10 minutes, painting a living portrait of Earth. On its first official day, the weather systems shown include typhoons spinning in the western Pacific.
McDonald's said it had no plans to stop distributing a talking Happy Meal toy inspired by the movie "Minions," even though some customers said it sounds as if it is cursing.

display_asset.caption: Novak Djokovic celebrated his victory over Richard Gasquet in a Wimbledon men's semifinal on Friday.

summaries.body: Novak Djokovic, above, defeated Richard Gasquet, 7-6 (2), 6-4, 6-4, to advance to his fourth Wimbledon final.
An appeals court upheld the conviction of Bob McDonnell, the former governor of Virginia, who was convicted last year of bribery and corruption.
Tunisia's Interior Ministry said security forces had killed five suspected extremists. The operation came after a gunman killed 38 tourists at a resort in June.
The police detained one of China’s most prominent human rights lawyers in Beijing, after an additional three rights lawyers disappeared in the capital within 24 hours.

display_asset.credit: Newsha Tavakolian/Magnum, for The New York Times

summaries.body: Thousands of people chanted "Down with America" and "Death to Israel" in annual rallies in Iran, as Iran and six nations held talks in Vienna on its nuclear program.
China's military will prosecute another former senior officer for corruption, the Defense Ministry said, part of a campaign that has already targeted dozens of top people.
Pilots flew two electric planes, one made by Airbus, across the English Channel for the first time, journeys seen as a step toward making such flights viable in the long term.

posts.footer: A Times correspondent on a meeting between top European officials to discuss the Greek debt crisis, via Twitter

summaries.body: Teleconference at 1pm between @JunckerEU, @Lagarde, @J_Dijsselbloem and Draghi on Greece proposal. @tsipras_eu #eurogroup
German police arrested a man in Bavaria suspected of shooting dead a woman from his Mercedes convertible, and then fatally shooting a cyclist.
Tunisia's prime minister said his country did "everything in our power" to protect tourists, after Britain said another attack was likely and urged its citizens to leave.
Citing concerns about music rights, the BBC has halted playing anything by Neil Young, the Doors, Journey or Bonnie Raitt — or even songs that sample their work.
Trying to address a housing shortage, Britain will announce new rules that include automatic approval for developments on land once used for industrial purposes.

posts.footer: Agence France-Presse, via The Straits Times

summaries.body: Rainfall last month appears to have "considerably eased" North Korea's drought, but key rice-producing areas are still afflicted, South Korea's Unification Ministry said.

posts.footer: The Times's Tehran bureau chief, covering annual protests against Israel and other perceived enemies of Iran, via Twitter

summaries.body: A group of kids carrying a banner saying: "resistance until victory." http://t.co/uISpT59z6V
United Airlines is investigating an incident in June in which a pilot dumped live ammunition down a toilet during a flight to Munich from Houston.

posts.footer: Panupong Sritananuwat, one of 14 Thai students recently jailed for protesting military rule, who said security personnel had shadowed them since their release this week, via The Nation

summaries.body: We are not criminals. They don't really need to follow us like this. I feel very unsafe indeed.
A North Korean pesticide factory recently visited by Kim Jong-un could be used to make "military-size batches of anthrax," the website 38 North reported.

posts.footer: Agence France-Presse, via The Straits Times

summaries.body: At least 17 people were killed in a stampede at a Bangladeshi factory compound where free clothes were being given away, the police said.
McDonald's denied that a talking "Minions" toy included in Happy Meals uses curse words, though "a very small number of customers" have complained that it does.
Indonesia closed five airports due to ash from a volcanic eruption. Thousands of travelers were stranded in Bali.

display_asset.caption: George W. Bush and Bill Clinton, at the ceremony for graduates of the Presidential Leadership Scholars program, held Thursday at the George W. Bush Presidential Center in Dallas.
display_asset.credit: Cooper neill for The New York Times

summaries.body: In a rare joint appearance, George W. Bush and Bill Clinton were all charm as they took the stage in Dallas to promote a scholarship program.
